There are a few people who have heard of Marilyn Monroe. She was, at one time many decades ago, a true icon. She is credited with these words, “A wise girl know her limits, a smart girl knows that she has none.” Excellent counsel for all of us. Often, we impose parameters on ourselves that needn’t be there. Societal norms will strap us with enough baggage we don’t need to add our own, or even add to others.

This poster was created by a 5th grader who is not a student at Franklin Discovery, but we appreciate the message. In fact, we are convinced the two terms are not mutually exclusive of one another and that EVERY child is both pretty AND smart. That is the message we want to drive home every day with our students. It is okay to compete but NEVER compare. Everyone excels at something so let’s concentrate on those attributes and skill-sets and not artificially limit ourselves or others. ‘Nuf said.

No question, these are tough times, and everyone has been and will continue to be impacted by the pandemic. We continue to focus on how to cope with our daily challenges and do what is best for our students. Our response is simply that your child’s education could move to a whole new level.

There are many roads to your destination. Some are shorter, some are faster, some rougher while others are smoother. But the one you want to take is the one most breathtaking. We don’t want to just be your elementary school, we want to part of your most fantastic journey, ever. Franklin Discovery Academy. In the heart of the pandemic, might these “soft skills” be more important than ever?

It takes all kinds! And Volunteers are at the top of the list. All schools rely on volunteers to help make the magic happen, and that is doubly true for charter schools. Our revenues are limited to State contributions based on enrollment so “balancing the ledgers” is critical to our financial stability. Therefore, and thusly, got to have those volunteer hours to meet the objectives of students, parents and staff.

One such volunteer is our very good friend and protector, Deputy Chad Stilson, with the Utah County Sheriff’s Office. While his primary goal is the safety and security of our students, somehow, he finds personal time to demonstrate his painting mastery. Prior to christening our new ship play structure, we determined that three coats of paint would protect our ship from the elements, and our little ship mates from slivers. Again, more labor and materials required, all coming from our budget. So, a little “free” labor is always appreciated. Turns out, he is pretty good with the paint sprayer!

Thank you, Deputy Stilson!

We found this on the internet, so it must be true, right? The website sleep.org states that children between the ages of six and 13 typically require 9 – 11 hours of sleep per day. And that does NOT count naps. It must all be at night. They further explain, “After all, growth hormone, which is essential for tissue growth and muscle development, is released during sleep. Repair to various organs, tissues, and muscles occurs during snooze time. And slumber is important for learning new information and solidifying long-term memories.”

Let’s help our students by ensuring they benefit from those wonderful nighty-night hours. Might it also be possible to make sure parents get their rest, as well?

Also, the development of the brain can be positively impacted by exploring different forms of communication. We are not aware of anyone whose IQ dropped, after learning another language.

-Access to the school library, resources, and printed curriculum and books for off-line use

-Access to School-at-Home online clubs to play with other Franklin Foxes: Chess club, Qwirkle club

-SPED services provided, per IEP

-Google Classroom with access to mentoring teacher, activities, and school friend connections

-Access to all on-site activities as determined appropriate by the family

We don’t always toot our own horn as often or loudly, as perhaps we should. The original design of our school incorporated unisex, single-user restrooms into every Homeroom classroom. All too often, it seems restrooms are a place of bullying, so we wanted to take that right out of the equation. In addition, new laws and regulation require that students can choose which restroom they want to utilize. By having single-use bathrooms, everyone uses the SAME bathrooms, but only one at a time.

Another benefit is that teachers know not only who is in the bathroom, but how long they have been there. It is called “classroom management” and we think it is a great idea. But it is not our only great idea.

Each Homeroom also has a refrigerator located in it. It allows staff and students to keep snacks and lunches cold and preserved. And if we have a refrigerator, we may as well incorporate a sink and microwave.

We certainly didn’t think of everything, but we did think of a lot!

From our perspective, one of the challenges associated with standardized testing is that schools are tempted to cut back on activities, such as recess, free-play and even the arts to accommodate standardized test preparation. We understand it, we just don’t agree with it.

Standardized testing also assumes all children develop and learn at the same pace. Science has documented that the younger the child, the more inaccurate the assumption becomes. When governing bodies talk about grade-level standards, they may be missing the mark. Teachers and Administrators are far more aware of your student’s development than a test may reveal. That is also why we incorporate Mastery Learning in our educational model. A student must prove they have “mastered” a concept before moving on to the next.

Yep! That’s us! Cannot, and will not, run from our DNA!

Daniel Koretz is a professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education and author of the book, ‘The Testing Charade’. Bari Walsh, also of Harvard School of Education, points out that “ . . . Koretz excoriates our current reliance on high-stakes testing as a fraud – an expense and harmful intervention that does little to improve the practices it purports to measure, instead feeding a vicious cycle of pointless test prep. The book’s title, ‘The Testing Charade’, captures his point; excessive high-stakes testing undermines the goals of instruction and meaningful learning.” https://www.gse.harvard.edu/news/uk/17/11/when-testing-takes-over

Is Daniel anti-standardized tests? Not at all . . . if used appropriately. Suffice it to say, Franklin Discovery maintains the downside of standardized testing, as we know it today, far outweighs the upside. Rather than focusing on test scores, we are going to concentrate on teaching our students to solve all types of problems, while developing as solid contributors to our society.

Lest there be any misunderstandings, we are not fans of standardized testing. Even Michelle Obama is credited with saying, “If my future were determined just by my performance on a standardized test, I wouldn’t be here. I can guarantee you that.”

In fact, our educational model is more closely aligned with Brene Brown’s thinking: “If you think dealing with issues like worthiness and authenticity and vulnerability are not worthwhile because there are more pressing issues, like the bottom line or attendance or standardized test scores, you are sadly, sadly mistaken. It underpins everything.”

I guess we’ll know soon enough, because all students will miss their annual standardized testing this year. It has been a challenging year for us all, but if standardized testing had somehow been thrown into the mix, there may have been a parental uprising.

Franklin Discovery will continue to promote the concept of lifelong learning over rote memorization.

Are you familiar with the phrase, “best-laid plans?” Yep, actually a translation of a Scottish proverb first published back in 1786 by Robert Burns. Mrs. Jack, our Executive Director, is very familiar with this phrase and the State announcement yesterday made things a wee bit more challenging for her . . . but imminently doable. See those broad shoulders of hers?

Everyone from the Governor to Franklin Discovery hoped to educate our students through our School-at-Home model for only the announced two weeks. Today, however, the State announced that the dismissal of public schools will continue until May 1st. We have long passed the familiar shoreline and are now in uncharted waters. One compelling reason for using mastery learning is due to the fact that students in today's schools are becoming more academically diverse. There are more students identified for more interventions in special education, more students for whom English is not their first language, more students struggling to read, and more students with socioeconomic disadvantages. There is a need to ensure advanced learners are appropriately challenged despite accountability pressures to focus on only basic competencies. It seems unrealistic to think that these diverse student groups will thrive in
classrooms that disregard their learning differences. We intend to apply a mastery learning model that recognizes instruction should be multifaceted, adapted to the context, tied to students' interests and experiences, and differentiated according to the knowledge, skills, dispositions, and background characteristics of students (Tomlinson, 2008).

post_text: Mastery learning is an educational approach, not specific content. Instruction can take place using any teaching method or style as long as a learning cycle of pre-assessment–instruction–assessment–enrichment or remediation–mastery is followed. Educators can apply mastery learning using a variety of pedagogical techniques. For instance, the “enrichment” activities Bloom described can be in the form of field trips, projects, performances, reading assignments, etc. Some of the types of activities important to the Founders that will be included in our educational approach include field trips, projects, music and arts, peer tutoring, peer teaching, student presentations, student journals, physical activities and wellness, and lab experiments. These specific educational approaches have documented research supporting their importance to student learning outcomes (Aslan, 2014).

“The more slowly trees grow at first, the sounder they are at the core, and I think the same is true of human beings.” -Henry David Thoreau

Developmentally appropriate practice (DAP) is an approach that was front-of-mind with the founding board of Franklin Discovery Academy. Each student develops and matures at different rates, so it only makes sense to us that we adapt our teaching to the individual student. We don’t all learn to walk at the same age, but we all seem to get there. Looking back, did it matter?

According to National Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC), teachers make decisions based on these three areas of knowledge:

-Knowing about child development and learning
-Knowing what is individually appropriate
-Knowing what is culturally appropriate

https://www.naeyc.org/resources/topics/dap/3-core-considerations

If your student is not at “grade-level” in the 1st, 2nd or 3rd grade, no worries! They are just developing their “core.”

According to the American Speech-Language Hearing Association (ASHA), children who have mild to moderate hearing loss but do not get intervention services are very likely to be behind their hearing peers by anywhere from one to four grade levels.

While hearing is often checked in schools, it is imperative that parents and guardians work closely with school staff to quickly identify any signs of hearing loss. Early intervention is key to a successful outcome. Healthy Hearing lists several signs that may indicate a potential hearing issue:

-Inappropriate responses to questions
-Daydreaming
-Trouble following directions
-Speech problems

Charter schools are public schools with a twist. They operate with a charter, or contract, between the school's governing board and the state of Utah. The charter gives the school's governing board the authority and autonomy to execute their unique mission and vision in exchange for accountability to standards set by the State.

Guess what? Sometimes our DNA does not neatly align with the expectation of governmental entities. According to our charter, we are not focused entirely on State assessments. We feel there are more appropriate, and more accurate methods by which to measure student development. This is not rebellion on our part, but carefully spelled out in our charter, which the State approved when they granted our charter.

So, will our scores on State assessments be among the highest? Unlikely. That was never our objective nor our mission. Our focus is on student development. We understand that not all families will be drawn to our school, but our success reinforces that many are. It is to those families that we pledge our very best.

In an earlier post we suggested that you pick one hour out of each work year, and that is the hour on which your performance for the entire year is evaluated. One hour out of the average 2,080-hour working year determines your “grade”. That is how our students are evaluated on subject retention and they don’t even get to pick the hour.

If it were only that simple. It is not only about the time spent on standardized testing, but additional tests and assessments are administered throughout the year, in preparation. For example, interim or benchmark tests. Some claim students can average as high as 16 hours during the year, testing.

And when you are testing, you may not be capitalizing on learning opportunities. Many teachers feel that time testing comes at the expense of instructional time. Do you really think teachers need students to take a standardized test to fully grasp their progress and knowledge? Ask a teacher and see what they say.

Learning is a life-long adventure. Does standardized testing enhance, or detract from, the adventure?

Besides, every smile brings joy to at least two people, ourselves and others we may meet.

Life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. An iconic phrase from our Declaration of Independence. Now, how about a little blasphemy that supports that phrase . . . No Assigned Homework! NOT at Franklin Discovery Academy. We know that children need time to participate in family activities, sports, and community events. Excessive homework can rob children of these activities, as well as result in poor sleep habits. Research has not been able to demonstrate a consistent, positive correlation between homework, learning, and improved test scores at the elementary level. For this reason, we do not have assigned homework. A parent may choose to have a student work on an assignment at home, or while traveling, but we will not require it.

Children need time outside of school for playing, exercising, doing chores, playing music, drawing pictures, exploring nature, reading for pleasure, discussing things with parents, and just goofing around. Therefore, Franklin Discovery Academy has chosen to say NO to homework.

Who has primary responsibility for educating a student? According to Utah Code (53A-15-1403), “A student’s parent or guardian is the primary person responsible for the education of the student, and the state is in a secondary and supportive role to the parent or guardian.”

Franklin Discovery Academy wholly endorses this philosophy and actively welcomes parent or guardian participation in the education of their students. The gist of this code is that schools must “reasonable accommodate” parent or guardian requests. For example, if parents or guardians want to hold a student back for another year, or not hold a student back, they can request the school accommodate their request. You may want to read this section of the code, yourself, to learn about other accommodations that may reasonably be requested. https://le.utah.gov/xcode/Title53A/Chapter15/C53A-15-S1403_2014040320140701.pdf

Homework. Does it make our children smarter, or even help them to learn more effectively? Not in our book! In fact,
just the opposite. In the early 1900’s, some districts even banned homework under seventh grade because it stressed out younger students. Concerns that the U.S. was falling behind the Soviet Union ignited a resurgence in homework but in the 60’s and 70’s, some viewed homework as stifling play and creativity. In the 80’s, thanks to government
researchers who blamed schools for the country’s economic troubles, the pressure was on for more homework, once more.
https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2019/03/homework-research-how-much/585889/

Franklin Discovery Academy does NOT assign homework. While many cannot agree on the science, we are strong
advocates for no homework. If there is an exception to that rule, it is parents reading with their children, at home. That is ALWAYS a good thing. Otherwise, six hours in a structured school setting is enough. Turn them loose for unstructured play and creativity. That is our story and we are sticking to it!

We do NOT feel that standardized testing is the perfect answer. Perhaps not even a poor answer. For one basic reason . . . standardized testing focuses solely on ACADEMIC growth and ignores the “soft skills” that are even more important to the overall education of our children. Standardized testing may not even properly address academic improvement. Franklin Discovery believes a partnership between parents and teachers will ensure students receive both the proper guidance and support.

Franklin Discovery Academy has our own model for keeping parents updated on their student’s growth, so more about that in later posts. Matt Damon, a well-known actor, seems to have a similar mindset, so we are not alone in our emphasis on providing a developmentally appropriate education. Remember, Learning should be a life-long adventure.

What is the difference between STRESS (Eustress) and DISTRESS? Many argue that stress may have positive impacts, but distress may be more negative. Vanderbilt University shared an article on their Center for Teaching website:

“Within the academic setting, causes of student distress may include:

- “Test anxiety, a form of performance anxiety where a person experiences high levels of distress or uneasiness before, during, or after an examination. Test anxiety interferes with students’ ability to perform in testing situations

- “Perfectionism, the need to be or appear perfect

- “Imposter syndrome, a persistent belief or feeling that one is inadequate even in the face of success

- “Stereotype threat, a self-confirming belief that one may be evaluated based on a negative stereotype of a group in which they belong

- “Generalized anxiety, ongoing anxiety and worry that interferes with day-to-day activities”

https://cft.vanderbilt.edu/guides-sub-pages/keeping-stress-from-evolving-into-distress/

MASTERY Learning Model - What is it? Mastery Learning is an instructional and educational philosophy proposed by Benjamin Bloom in 1968. Mastery Learning allows a student to move forward, AFTER having shown “mastery” in the current area of study. Two critical components of Mastery Learning include direct feedback to the student and allowing the student to move at their own pace of learning. If a student is unable to achieve mastery in a particular subject, they receive additional instruction to insure they can master and move to the next section.

Bloom predicted that “95% of the students taught by the mastery approach would achieve at a level that had previously been reached by only 5%”.
(http://www.nyu.edu/classes/keefer/waoe/motamediv.htm)

There are detractors to Bloom’s position, and the above referenced article makes for an interesting read.

“Boys Who Sit Still Have a Harder Time Learning to Read.” This is the title of an article published by Belinda Luscombe in Time Magazine (June 8, 2017). The pronouncement was based on a Finnish study released in the Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport. The study states that the more time boys spend sitting in first grade, with less physical activity, the fewer gains they made in reading the two following years. A lot of sedentary time and little physical activity also had a negative impact on learning math.

On the other hand, a lack of activity didn’t seem to impact girls, at all. Granted, it was a small study but might be worth reading. https://time.com/4588035/sitting-exercise-reading/

In days of yore, students LEARNED how to do things. They learned through instruction and study and then executed their newfound knowledge.

Today’s students are different. They learn by DOING. Gone are the days of instruction manuals and learning first, doing second. Students are learning through experiential opportunities. They learn based on participation and observation.

Give your grandparents a new smart phone and chances are they might be a wee bit lost. Heaven forbid they touch a wrong button and the phone disappears. Give a 5-year old a new smart phone and it won’t be long before they are at least conversant with many of the apps on the phone. They are not afraid to push all the buttons and try new things. They master the phone through continual experimentation and hands-on trial.

Maybe, just maybe, that model might be beneficial in an educational environment? We certainly think so!

Will my child LOVE attending Franklin Discovery Academy, but suffer academically? Nope! No Way! Just won’t happen!

Unless . . . the only definition of “suffering academically” is your child testing at an arbitrary level, at one specific moment in time, on a specific day in May.

Research in Brain Function and Learning by Margaret Semrud-Clikeman, PhD, LP, ABPdN, University of Minnesota Medical School (https://www.apa.org/education/k12/brain-function):

The brain begins to mature even before birth. Although it continues to mature throughout most of life, the brain does not mature at the same rate in each individual.

This should not be surprising. After all, our bodies grow at different rates — we reach puberty at different ages and our emotional maturity at different times as well. Why should our brains be any different?

Just because you have a classroom full of students who are about the same age doesn't mean they are equally ready to learn a particular topic, concept, skill, or idea. It is important for teachers and parents to understand that maturation of the brain influences learning readiness. For teachers, this is especially important when designing lessons and selecting which strategies to use.

It’s end-of-year testing time at Franklin Discovery. As a school, we have a philosophical concern with reducing your child to a number. We think this visual is a great reminder than your student is so much more than a test score.

We administer the tests as required by law, but this year we have not been very excited about it because we do not have much confidence in the test. Utah switched to a new end-of-year test this year and there have been serious statewide issues with the test itself. We’ve gotten emails daily from the testing company about various problems and outages. KSL has run several stories about the numerous delays and issues. We have no confidence this year’s test will be reporting reliable results. Even Utah's top education official has expressed doubt over the reliability of results (see article in comments). We have already seen discrepancies between the scores displayed to students and the scores reported to their teacher. We are being dutiful and administering the test as required, but our focus remains on educating beyond the test.
